title: Evolution in a big city - Jason Munshi-South

multiple-choice.question: What is the main focus of the speaker's research in New York City?

options.label: A
options.text: Studying the behavior of coyotes in urban environments.

options.label: B
options.text: Understanding how native wildlife adapts to urban environments.

options.label: C
options.text: Investigating the impact of climate change on urban ecosystems.

options.label: D
options.text: Examining the effects of pollution on human health.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the forested hillside in Northern Manhattan mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It is home to a large population of coyotes.

options.label: B
options.text: It is one of the last areas in the city with clean spring water.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a popular spot for birdwatching.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a designated nature reserve.

multiple-choice.question: What has the speaker's lab found about the northern dusky salamanders on the hillside?

options.label: A
options.text: They are able to migrate across the city.

options.label: B
options.text: They are only found on one side of the bridges.

options.label: C
options.text: They can be identified by their DNA as coming from one side of the bridge or the other.

options.label: D
options.text: They are extinct in the city.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the speaker interested in studying coyotes in New York City?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are a new species in the city.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are a threat to human safety.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are adapting to urban environments.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are an invasive species.

multiple-choice.question: What is the white-footed mouse, and why is it important to the speaker's research?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an invasive species, and the speaker is studying its impact on native ecosystems.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a native species, and the speaker is using it as a model to understand adaptation to urban environments.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a common pest, and the speaker is studying ways to control its population.

options.label: D
options.text: It is an endangered species, and the speaker is working to conserve it.

multiple-choice.question: How has the speaker's research shown that the white-footed mouse has adapted to urban environments?

options.label: A
options.text: By studying its behavior in different parks.

options.label: B
options.text: By analyzing its DNA and finding genetic differences between populations in different parks.

options.label: C
options.text: By observing its diet and finding that it has changed in response to urbanization.

options.label: D
options.text: By tracking its population size and finding that it has increased in urban areas.

multiple-choice.question: What is a Manhattan plot, and how is it used in the speaker's research?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a type of graph used to show the genetic differences between populations.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a statistical method used to analyze large datasets.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a type of trap used to catch mice.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a software program used to analyze DNA sequences.

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the genes that have been found to be different between city and country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: Genes related to immune response, metabolism, and heavy-metal tolerance.

options.label: B
options.text: Genes related to coat color, size, and behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: Genes related to diet, habitat, and predator avoidance.

options.label: D
options.text: Genes related to reproduction, development, and growth.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the speaker encouraging the audience to look at their parks in a new way?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are trying to promote conservation efforts.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they want people to appreciate the beauty of nature.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they believe that people can make new discoveries by observing their surroundings.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are trying to raise awareness about the impact of urbanization on wildlife.

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall message of the speaker's talk?

options.label: A
options.text: That urbanization is a major threat to biodiversity.

options.label: B
options.text: That wildlife can adapt to urban environments in surprising ways.

options.label: C
options.text: That scientists should focus on studying urban ecosystems.

options.label: D
options.text: That conservation efforts should prioritize protecting natural habitats.

title: How containerization shaped the modern world - Sir Harold Evans

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the process of shipping goods around the world at a minimal cost?

options.label: A
options.text: Globalization

options.label: B
options.text: Containerization

options.label: C
options.text: Break bulk shipping

options.label: D
options.text: Free trade

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with inventing the concept of containerization?

options.label: A
options.text: Malcolm McLean

options.label: B
options.text: Steve Jobs

options.label: C
options.text: Henry Ford

options.label: D
options.text: Thomas Edison

multiple-choice.question: What was Malcolm McLean's occupation when he first thought of the concept of containerization?

options.label: A
options.text: Truck driver

options.label: B
options.text: Ship captain

options.label: C
options.text: Businessman

options.label: D
options.text: Inventor

multiple-choice.question: What problem did Malcolm McLean face that led him to think of the concept of containerization?

options.label: A
options.text: He was tired of driving long distances.

options.label: B
options.text: He was frustrated with the slow process of loading and unloading goods from ships.

options.label: C
options.text: He was having trouble finding work during the Great Depression.

options.label: D
options.text: He was struggling to make a profit with his trucking company.

multiple-choice.question: How did Malcolm McLean's concept of containerization revolutionize the shipping industry?

options.label: A
options.text: It increased the cost of shipping goods.

options.label: B
options.text: It decreased the time it took to load and unload goods from ships.

options.label: C
options.text: It reduced the number of jobs available in the shipping industry.

options.label: D
options.text: It limited the types of goods that could be shipped.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of Malcolm McLean's first container ship?

options.label: A
options.text: The Ideal X

options.label: B
options.text: The Container King

options.label: C
options.text: The Global Trader

options.label: D
options.text: The Sea Dragon

multiple-choice.question: How many containers did the Ideal X carry on its first voyage?
What was the result of Malcolm McLean's invention of containerization?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a decline in global trade.

options.label: B
options.text: It increased the cost of goods for consumers.

options.label: C
options.text: It created a thriving global marketplace with a wide variety of goods.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on the economy.

multiple-choice.question: How did Malcolm McLean fund his containerization project?

options.label: A
options.text: He used his own savings.

options.label: B
options.text: He borrowed money from a bank.

options.label: C
options.text: He received funding from the government.

options.label: D
options.text: He partnered with another company.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the process of shipping goods in individual pieces, rather than in containers?

options.label: A
options.text: Break bulk shipping

options.label: B
options.text: Containerization

options.label: C
options.text: Globalization

options.label: D
options.text: Free trade

title: Poetic stickup: Put the financial aid in the bag - Carvens Lissaint

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's primary concern in this poem?

options.label: A
options.text: The high cost of living

options.label: B
options.text: The difficulty of finding a job

options.label: C
options.text: The struggle to obtain financial aid for education

options.label: D
options.text: The importance of getting good grades

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's tone in this poem?

options.label: A
options.text: Calm and collected

options.label: B
options.text: Angry and frustrated

options.label: C
options.text: Happy and optimistic

options.label: D
options.text: Sad and depressed

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker compare the struggle for financial aid to?

options.label: A
options.text: A game

options.label: B
options.text: A war

options.label: C
options.text: A fight for civil rights

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: Who does the speaker mention as an example of someone who fought for the opportunity to get an education?

options.label: A
options.text: Their great-great-great-grandfather

options.label: B
options.text: A historical figure such as Martin Luther King Jr.

options.label: C
options.text: A friend or family member

options.label: D
options.text: A fictional character

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker accuse the system of doing to students?

options.label: A
options.text: Helping them achieve their goals

options.label: B
options.text: Providing them with adequate financial aid

options.label: C
options.text: Strangling the life out of their bank statements

options.label: D
options.text: Giving them too much money

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker compare the lecture halls to?

options.label: A
options.text: A place of freedom and learning

options.label: B
options.text: A cotton field

options.label: C
options.text: A prison cell

options.label: D
options.text: A playground

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to the system?

options.label: A
options.text: To keep doing what they're doing

options.label: B
options.text: To make it easier for students to get financial aid

options.label: C
options.text: To stop thieving students' aspirations

options.label: D
options.text: To give up on education altogether

multiple-choice.question: Who does the speaker mention as someone who is affected by the struggle for financial aid?

options.label: A
options.text: Only themselves

options.label: B
options.text: Their friends and family members

options.label: C
options.text: People in Haiti who don't have access to education

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's ultimate goal?

options.label: A
options.text: To get rich

options.label: B
options.text: To get a good job

options.label: C
options.text: To get an education and grow as a person

options.label: D
options.text: To give up on life

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final request to the system?

options.label: A
options.text: To take away their financial aid

options.label: B
options.text: To make it harder for students to get financial aid

options.label: C
options.text: To put the money in the bag and help students achieve their goals

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore their pleas for help

title: The power of simple words - Terin Izil

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the passage about words and language?

options.label: A
options.text: Using complex vocabulary is essential for effective writing.

options.label: B
options.text: The use of simple words is often more effective than using complex vocabulary.

options.label: C
options.text: Writers should always use a thesaurus to find alternative words.

options.label: D
options.text: Writing should be aimed at a fourth-grade reading level.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the author think that Aerosmith would not have had a hit with "Ambulate This Direction"?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the lyrics would be too short.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the lyrics would be too long.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the words would be too complex and not catchy.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the song would be too slow.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the problem with using $10 words?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too expensive to use.

options.label: B
options.text: They are not understood by most people.

options.label: C
options.text: They are too short and lack impact.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too common and overused.

multiple-choice.question: Who is the author referring to when they mention the phrase "Provide me with liberty or bestow upon me fatality"?

options.label: A
options.text: L. Frank Baum

options.label: B
options.text: Patrick Henry

options.label: C
options.text: Dorothy from The Wizard of Oz

options.label: D
options.text: The author of the passage

multiple-choice.question: What does the author mean by "know your audience" in the context of writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Understand the demographics of your readers.

options.label: B
options.text: Use language that is tailored to your readers' level of understanding.

options.label: C
options.text: Write only for a specific age group.

options.label: D
options.text: Ignore the needs of your readers.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the author think that brevity is important in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Because readers have a short attention span.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is easier to write short sentences.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is more cost-effective to use fewer words.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is more creative to use fewer words.

multiple-choice.question: What does the author mean by "competing against a whole world of distractions"?

options.label: A
options.text: Writers are competing against other writers for readers' attention.

options.label: B
options.text: Writers are competing against other forms of media for readers' attention.

options.label: C
options.text: Writers are competing against their own ideas for readers' attention.

options.label: D
options.text: Writers are competing against their own writing style for readers' attention.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's attitude towards using complex vocabulary in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: The author is in favor of using complex vocabulary.

options.label: B
options.text: The author is neutral about using complex vocabulary.

options.label: C
options.text: The author is skeptical about using complex vocabulary.

options.label: D
options.text: The author is against using complex vocabulary.

multiple-choice.question: What does the author mean by "variety may be the spice of life, but brevity is its bread and butter"?

options.label: A
options.text: Variety is more important than brevity in writing.

options.label: B
options.text: Brevity is more important than variety in writing.

options.label: C
options.text: Variety and brevity are equally important in writing.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither variety nor brevity is important in writing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's final advice to writers regarding $10 words?

options.label: A
options.text: Use them sparingly to add flavor to your writing.

options.label: B
options.text: Use them frequently to show off your vocabulary.

options.label: C
options.text: Save your money and buy a Scrabble board.

options.label: D
options.text: Avoid using them altogether.

title: Symbiosis: A surprising tale of species cooperation - David Gonzales

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for a partnership between two different species where both species depend on each other?

options.label: A
options.text: Mutualism

options.label: B
options.text: Symbiosis

options.label: C
options.text: Parasitism

options.label: D
options.text: Commensalism

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the bird that has a symbiotic relationship with the whitebark pine tree?

options.label: A
options.text: Clark's sparrow

options.label: B
options.text: Clark's finch

options.label: C
options.text: Clark's nutcracker

options.label: D
options.text: Clark's woodpecker

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the cones of the whitebark pine tree?

options.label: A
options.text: They are very small

options.label: B
options.text: They are very colorful

options.label: C
options.text: They are packed with protein

options.label: D
options.text: They are very heavy

multiple-choice.question: What do squirrels do with the cones of the whitebark pine tree?

options.label: A
options.text: They eat them immediately

options.label: B
options.text: They bury them in piles

options.label: C
options.text: They hide them in their nests

options.label: D
options.text: They give them to the Clark's nutcracker

options.label: A
options.text: They ignore them

options.label: B
options.text: They destroy them

options.label: C
options.text: They use them to build their nests

options.label: D
options.text: They love finding and eating them

options.label: A
options.text: It eats them all immediately

options.label: B
options.text: It stores them in its nest

options.label: C
options.text: It caches them in the forest

options.label: D
options.text: It gives them to other birds

multiple-choice.question: How many seeds can the Clark's nutcracker store in its throat pouch?

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 20 seeds

options.label: B
options.text: Up to 40 seeds

options.label: C
options.text: Up to 60 seeds

options.label: D
options.text: Up to 80 seeds

multiple-choice.question: How do Clark's nutcrackers remember where they cached their seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: They use their sense of smell

options.label: B
options.text: They use landmarks on the landscape

options.label: C
options.text: They use their sense of hearing

options.label: D
options.text: They use their sense of touch

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the seeds that the Clark's nutcracker does not retrieve?

options.label: A
options.text: They are eaten by other animals

options.label: B
options.text: They are destroyed by the weather

options.label: C
options.text: They become whitebark pine trees

options.label: D
options.text: They are used by other birds

multiple-choice.question: How have the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine tree evolved to suit each other?

options.label: A
options.text: The nutcracker has developed a shorter beak, and the whitebark pine tree has developed smaller cones

options.label: B
options.text: The nutcracker has developed a longer beak, and the whitebark pine tree has developed branches that sweep upwards

options.label: C
options.text: The nutcracker has developed stronger wings, and the whitebark pine tree has developed deeper roots

options.label: D
options.text: The nutcracker has developed better eyesight, and the whitebark pine tree has developed more colorful cones

title: How many universes are there? - Chris Anderson

multiple-choice.question: How many Earths can fit inside the sun?

options.label: C
options.text: 1 million

options.label: D
options.text: 10 million

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many stars are in the Milky Way galaxy?

options.label: A
options.text: 100 million

options.label: B
options.text: 400 billion

options.label: C
options.text: 1 trillion

options.label: D
options.text: 10 trillion

multiple-choice.question: How many galaxies are detectable by our telescopes?

options.label: A
options.text: 10 million

options.label: B
options.text: 100 million

options.label: C
options.text: 1 billion

options.label: D
options.text: 100 billion

multiple-choice.question: According to recent theories in physics, what could be the number of universes in the multiverse?

options.label: A
options.text: 100 billion

options.label: C
options.text: 1 trillion

options.label: D
options.text: Infinity

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of the multiverse in physics?

options.label: A
options.text: A single universe with multiple dimensions

options.label: B
options.text: A collection of universes with different properties and laws

options.label: C
options.text: A theory that describes the behavior of particles in our universe

options.label: D
options.text: A concept that describes the expansion of space

options.label: A
options.text: Finite and bounded

options.label: B
options.text: Infinite and containing pocket universes

options.label: C
options.text: Expanding at an accelerating pace

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of parallel universes in quantum theory?

options.label: A
options.text: Universes that exist in parallel dimensions

options.label: B
options.text: Universes that are spawned every moment and contain multiple copies of us

options.label: C
options.text: Universes that are separated from us by vast distances

options.label: D
options.text: Universes that are identical to our own

options.label: A
options.text: 1 to 10

options.label: C
options.text: 1 to infinity

options.label: D
options.text: 0 to infinity

multiple-choice.question: What is the current state of agreement among scientists on the question of how many universes there are?

options.label: A
options.text: There is a consensus on a single answer

options.label: B
options.text: There are two competing theories

options.label: C
options.text: There is no agreement, with answers ranging from 0 to infinity

options.label: D
options.text: The question is no longer relevant in modern physics

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential implication of the current research in physics?

options.label: A
options.text: A minor adjustment to our understanding of the universe

options.label: B
options.text: A major paradigm shift in our understanding of the universe

options.label: C
options.text: A confirmation of existing theories

options.label: D
options.text: A rejection of existing theories

title: How simple ideas lead to scientific discoveries - Adam Savage

multiple-choice.question: What sparked Richard Feynman's interest in science as a young boy?

options.label: A
options.text: His father's explanation of inertia.

options.label: B
options.text: His discovery of a new species of plants.

options.label: C
options.text: His observation of the stars in the night sky.

options.label: D
options.text: His reading of science books in the library.

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with being the first person to accurately measure the circumference of the Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Eratosthenes

options.label: B
options.text: Aristotle

options.label: C
options.text: Galileo

options.label: D
options.text: Richard Feynman

options.label: B
options.text: By measuring the distance between two cities and using the angle of the sun's shadow.

options.label: C
options.text: By using a wheel to measure the speed of light.

options.label: D
options.text: By observing the stars in the night sky.

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea that the speaker is trying to convey about science?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is a closed, black box that only experts can understand.

options.label: B
